text:
Just like the "default" attribute of a <project/> element, which can be
specified to indicate which target to execute by default, ant should also
provide an "init" attribute to indicate a target to execute before any other
targets _IF_ it exists and a "final" target to execute after all other targets
_IF_ it exists.

Ex:

<project init="start" default="all" final="end">

   <target name="init">
      <taskdef name="foo" classname="my.custom.class"/>
   </target>

   <target name="all">
      <echo message="Hello World"/>
   </target>

</project>


From the above, typing "ant" would run the "init" target and then the "all"
target, but since there is no final target present then it will simply end like
normal.  However typing "ant all" would still run the "init" target followed by
the "all" target.
creator: binyan357@yahoo.com

I screwed that up and the correct build.xml is below

<project init="init" default="all" final="end">

   <target name="init">
      <taskdef name="foo" classname="my.custom.class"/>
   </target>

   <target name="all">
      <echo message="Hello World"/>
   </target>

</project>

text: *** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 17973 ***

In ant 1.5 you can put a taskdef outside of any target to have it run first; in
ant1.6 anything goes. This is an implicit init target. 

<project init="init" default="all" final="end">
   <taskdef name="foo" classname="my.custom.class"/>

   <target name="all">
      <echo message="Hello World"/>
   </target>

</project>

text:
While going through your comments on the bug, you mentioned the following build 
script:
<project init="init" default="all" final="end"> 

......

</project>

I submitted the earlier bug #17973 that is marked as a duplicate of this bug.

In the build script, you have used the "final" property for the project core 
task. However, I am unable to find the property in the documentation and also 
tried the same build script with Ant 1.5.1 and Ant 1.5.3. Is this a 
undocumented feature, or is it going to be included in next feature.

Oh, I was just being wrong -or more precisely cutting and pasting without
reading what I was pasting...I should have deleted the init and final attributes
from <project>

There is no (longer) an init, there is no final. But there is an implicit init
in ant1.6 of every task you stick outside a target
